simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its thoughtful, human-first take on alien contact hit my sweet spot for smart sci-fi.

simulated_ratings.feeling: High-concept thrills with emotional stakes and puzzle-box craft kept me hooked.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Rivalry and obsession woven into a clever mystery that pays off without losing the heart.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and moody, a bit slow for me but the ideas and world-building worked.

simulated_ratings.feeling: A gripping, grounded dystopia with urgency and heart that lingered after.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, morally thorny, and absorbing in that procedural way I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meticulous, patient investigation that quietly burrowed under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Shutter Island (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric and twisty, engaging even if a touch overcooked.

simulated_ratings.title: Knives Out (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A witty, well-clocked whodunit that entertained without overreaching.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nice Guys (2016)

simulated_ratings.title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy (2011)

simulated_ratings.title: The Post (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sturdy newsroom drama that hits the notes even if it feels familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: All the President's Men (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Absorbing, methodical journalism that scratches my investigative itch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Insider (1999)

simulated_ratings.title: A Few Good Men (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rousing courtroom fireworks anchored by strong moral stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lives of Others (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly devastating surveillance drama with humanity at its core.

simulated_ratings.title: Heat (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Epic cops-and-robbers chess match with crackling momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Polished, twisty noir with satisfying moral complexity.

simulated_ratings.title: Wind River (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber and tense, effective more for mood and setting than surprise.

simulated_ratings.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic, nail-biting mystery that unfolds with great control.

simulated_ratings.title: Get Out (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever and unsettling, more sharp social satire than outright scares for me.

simulated_ratings.title: A Quiet Place (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, inventive survival horror that kept me tense if not deeply moved.

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)

recommended_movies: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: The Martian (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ingenious, upbeat survival science and team problem‑solving hit my smart‑sci‑fi sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever time‑loop mechanics and brisk, witty action kept me fully engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Looper (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intriguing time‑travel noir with moral bite, even if the world‑building gets a little shaggy.

simulated_ratings.title: Moon (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, intimate sci‑fi mystery that rewards patience more than thrills, but it stuck with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Contact (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thoughtful, human‑scaled first‑contact drama with just enough wonder to carry the sermonizing.

simulated_ratings.title: Source Code (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tight, clockwork mystery that’s fun and tense, even if its emotions don’t cut too deep.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicario (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Nerve‑shredding, morally murky and impeccably controlled—right in my crime‑thriller wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek and unsettling character study with a queasy momentum I couldn’t look away from.

simulated_ratings.title: Collateral (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, nocturnal cat‑and‑mouse with great propulsion and just enough character heft.

simulated_ratings.title: The Departed (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Violent, twisty cops‑and‑crooks chess match that delivers tension and payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: No Country for Old Men (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Immaculate tension and menace, though its austere, fatalistic chill kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Michael Clayton (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cool, quietly gripping corporate thriller with moral stakes that hooked me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Constant Gardener (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Measured, empathetic conspiracy drama—absorbing more for its investigation and grief than shocks.

simulated_ratings.title: Zero Dark Thirty (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold, methodical manhunt that scratches my procedural itch and sustains real tension.

simulated_ratings.title: Munich (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber, morally tangled and strong, if a bit long‑winded for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conversation (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A precise, paranoid slow burn that gets under the skin in the best investigative way.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinatown (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Polished, twisty noir with moral rot that steadily tightens the screws.

simulated_ratings.title: The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A taut psychological hunt with unforgettable interplay and perfectly metered dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fincher‑clean investigation—bleak, propulsive, and satisfyingly knotty.

simulated_ratings.title: Inside Man (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clever, crowd‑pleasing heist puzzle that entertains even if it’s a touch lightweight.

simulated_ratings.title: Fargo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny, quietly brutal, and deceptively sharp—my kind of offbeat investigation.

simulated_ratings.title: In Bruges (2008)

simulated_ratings.title: Memento (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A brilliantly engineered puzzle with emotional stakes—exactly the kind of heady thriller I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: The Sixth Sense (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, tender ghost story with a twist that deepens rather than cheapens the drama.

simulated_ratings.title: The Others (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric and controlled, more about creeping unease than scares—and that worked for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Free Solo (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A jaw‑dropping feat filmed with real, sweaty‑palmed tension—even if the doc framing is straightforward.

simulated_ratings.title: The Imposter (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stranger‑than‑fiction investigation that unfolds like a thriller—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive and tender, admired more for its ideas and craft than it moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Memories of Murder (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Absorbing, bleak investigation with a lingering sting—patient but deeply rewarding.

simulated_ratings.title: Predestination (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A twisty, tightly engineered time‑travel puzzle with moral stakes that hit my heady‑thriller sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
